text: How do you feel about salespeople creating (or curating) their own content? What policies or guidelines does your company have in place to encourage, limit, or exercise quality control over such content?

elements.text: How do you feel about salespeople creating (or curating) their own content? What policies or guidelines does your company have in place to encourage, limit, or exercise quality control over such content?

text: IMO, a successful sales pro is your best opportunity for iterative A/B testing on messaging and content. They're selling the same product or services multiple times to multiple personas. If they tell me a piece of messaging or collateral works better than others, it's worth noting. We try to limit available approved materials to a specific shared drive so we can remove or refresh pieces as needed with updated branding, messaging, or data.

elements.text: IMO, a successful sales pro is your best opportunity for iterative A/B testing on messaging and content. They're selling the same product or services multiple times to multiple personas. If they tell me a piece of messaging or collateral works better than others, it's worth noting. We try to limit available approved materials to a specific shared drive so we can remove or refresh pieces as needed with updated branding, messaging, or data.

text: <@UJS103D7S> Thanks for your response and your insight. I hadn’t thought about the opportunity for testing messaging and content. It  ‘s not clear to me from your answer whether your company encourages or discourages reps with respect to creating their own content. If you encourage it, what guidelines or quality-control standards do you offer them?

elements.text: Thanks for your response and your insight. I hadn’t thought about the opportunity for testing messaging and content. It  ‘s not clear to me from your answer whether your company encourages or discourages reps with respect to creating their own content. If you encourage it, what guidelines or quality-control standards do you offer them?

text: I would say we encourage reps to suggest and guide content creation, including working with Marketing to build branded decks, ebooks & 1-sheeters, but we don't really condone them making it themselves

elements.text: I would say we encourage reps to suggest and guide content creation, including working with Marketing to build branded decks, ebooks & 1-sheeters, but we don't really condone them making it themselves

text: <@UJS103D7S> Thanks again for your fast reply! Hope I’m not being a pest. I’d really like to understand how various companies handle a common issue. Looks like Zylo sells fairly high-ticket SaaS to fairly big companies. Unless your company is an exception, you must get comments from sales reps who say they aren’t getting enough good leads from your content. If I were an enterprising and impatient rep, I wouldn’t wait for weeks for Marketing to produce the content I need. I’d do it myself, rather than risk getting fired for missing my quota. So how would you (or do you) handle it when this situation arises? Also, do you have social media guidelines or policies for your reps?
